Consistent with Cristal GlobalÂ¿s corporate commitment to Safety, Health, and Environmental Standards, the International Titanium Powder (ITP), LLC facilityÂ¿s written policy provides the foundation for Risk Management programs and activities within the Ottawa Illinois facility.  In keeping with this commitment, the ITP facility has established a comprehensive Safety Management System that strives to identify, control, and eliminate potential release of hazardous chemicals and exposures to employees, community, and the environment.  In addition, this risk Management Program includes accidental release prevention and emergency response plans and procedures. This Safety Management System and philosophy embodies and employs the spirit and intent of the concepts found in the OSHA Process Safety Management Standard, and  other applicable regulatory standards ,including those implemented by a sister company, Millennium Inorganic Chemicals, Inc. 

The major chemical that the ITP Ottawa facility uses to manufacture an inorganic chemical is liquid Titanium Tetrachloride (TiCl4), and the facility itself, as a Â¿Basic Inorganic Chemical ManufacturingÂ¿ facility,  is included within  NAICS # 325188.  The inventory quantities of Titanium Tetrachloride (TiCl4) retained on site is in excess of the EPA threshold of 2,500 lbs, and if released, would impact the local community.  Based upon these criteria, the ITP Ottawa facility is subject to the requirements of EPAÂ¿s RMP Program 3, which imposes OSHAÂ¿s Standard 1910.119 for Process Safety Management.

The goal of the Plant Safety Management System is to control potential exposures that include, but are not limited to, personal injury/illness, property damage, fires, impacts to local community and the environment, and process incidents and breaches of security. 

In support of this goal, the plant design and construction were performed to the most strict industry and code standards (ASME, ASCE, NFPA, NEC, Crist

al Global Industry Accepted & Proven Materials, Pipe, Welding Standards, etc); 

 
The ITP Safety Management System includes the following policy statement.

Â¿It is the facilityÂ¿s policy to adhere to all applicable federal and state rules and regulations for accidental release prevention and emergency response. Although the ultimate responsibility for safety and loss prevention at this location rests with the Plant Manager, specific safety responsibilities are assigned to all levels of management. Management at the ITP Ottawa facility has authorized specific risk management programs and activities in compliance with EPA's "Risk Management Program" requirements (40 CFR Part 68) that:

Description of International Titanium Powder Facility, Ottawa, Illinois and How Regulated Substance Is Handled

The International Titanium Powder Facility located at 1501 Titanium Drive in Ottawa, Illinois produces pure titanium

metal powder and titanium alloy metal powder for shipment to external users. The covered process is the patented "Armstrong Process (trademarked process)," for the low-cost production of high-purity titanium and titanium alloy powders. The detailed process design and operating procedures for this process are proprietary.  This process handles one chemical included on the EPA regulated list, namely titanium tetrachloride (CAS Number 7550-45-0).  Titanium Tetrachloride liquid is shipped to ITP in rail cars and/or truck trailers, and is transferred via pump from rail car/truck to a main steel storage tank.  The main storage tank resides within a building with a controlled environment.  All transfer pipe used in Titanium Tetrachloride service is of welded metal construction (except for some pumps and serviceable equipment).  Where bolt-up connections occur, the flanges are wrapped with suitable covers. Titanium tetrachloride (TiCl4) liquid is pumped from the rail car to the main storage tank, and separate pumps transfer liquid from the main storage tank to a vaporizer where the liquid is converted to a vapor.  Then the vapor is pressure transferred forwarded to a reactor area where it is pre-heated and then to the reactor where it is  mixed with a reducing agent to produce pure titanium metal powder (Ti).  Similarly, Titanium Tetrachloride (TiCl4) is reacted with a reducing agent and other metal chlorides to produce pure titanium alloy metal powder (Ti-M1-M2).  Once the reaction has occurred, the Titanium Tetrachloride and other metal chlorides are completely consumed. The powder and intermediates are further processed to remove by-product residuals from the Ti / Ti alloy materials, and prepared for packaging / shipping.  




Worst Case Release Scenario

RMP regulations require performing a consequence analysis for one worst case release scenario, estimated to present the greatest distance in any direction to a toxic endpoint.  The worst case release scenario (WCS) is

presented in the ITP Ottawa FacilityÂ¿s RMP*eSubmit submission.  The Worst Case scenario for the Ottawa site is consistent with similar events described at other Cristal Global sites (for Chlorine Rail Car releases) Â¿ a massive spill event.  The Worst Case scenario for the Ottawa facility is  a ground-level spill of 200,000 lbs. of liquid titanium tetrachloride from a rail car located outside of the buildings (where limited control is available).  The entire contents of the rail care are released from a structural failure of the rail vessel resulting in a release  rate of _700 gpm (10,000 #/min). for a duration of 20_ minutes. Based upon the local topography, a ground based spill area was estimated at 7,200 sq. ft. (120 ft x 60 ft).  The release of Titanium Tetrachloride vapor from a liquid pool is via surface evaporation.   The Model conditions followed 40 CFR 68.22, and included the following: 100% pure Titanium Tetrachloride, temp. 105 oF (max. summertime temps.) , Urban setting, wind speed 1.5 meters/sec,  default Atmospheric Stability class D.

Using the toxic endpoint of titanium tetrachloride of 0.20 mg/L, and assuming that the atmospheric release occurs at ground level, the EPAÂ¿s RMP Comp Model projects a  distance from the release point to be 3.8 miles, which is beyond the boundaries of the stationary source.  

The ITP Ottawa facility has available a portable foam suppression system to respond to such a release, thus reducing the extent of fume migration from the release point.

Using the toxic endpoint of titanium tetrachloride of 0.20 mg/L, and assuming that the atmospheric release occurs at ground level, the EPAÂ¿s RMP Comp Model projects a  distance from the release point to be 1.1 miles, which is beyond the boundaries of the stationary source.  




Alternative Case Release Scenarios

RMP regulations require that at least one alternative release scenario be identified and analyzed for each regulated toxic chemical present. The regulations require that a scenario that is more realistic than the worst case scenario is selected as the alternative release.  The Alternative Release Scenarios (ACRS) for titanium tetrachloride are:

1) The release of liquid from a transfer line while moving liquid from a rail car/truck to main storage tank.  Temperature is 105 oF and the release rate is 900 #/min for 5 minutes.
2) The release of liquid from a transfer line while moving liquid from the main storage tank to the vaporizers.  Temperature is 105 oF and release rate is 90 #/minute for 5

minutes.
3) The release of vapor from a transfer line on the way to the reactor.  Temperature is 428 oF and the release rate is 40 #/minute for 5 minutes.
4) The release of superheated vapor from a line just before the reactor.  Temperature is 617 oF and the release rate is 40 #/minute for 5 minutes.


All releases occur within enclosed process buildings, and these buildings are equipped with fugitive fume smoke detectors and pick-up ducts which lead to a fume scrubber.   The RMP Comp Program estimates the toxic endpoint distance from the 4 alternate sources to be 0.1 mile (528 ft).  The detection of a release followed by immediate action by a fume scrubber is major contributors to minimizing off-site impacts.  The only nearby commercial (no residential) businesses are greater than 0.1 mile from the ITP Facilty. 

 

Offsite Impacts Â¿Environment

There is a Wetlands Area within Â½ mile of the ITP Ottawa facility that discharges into the Illinois River.  Based upon the worst case scenario, the wetland areas would be impacted.  Based upon 4 alternate case scenarios, the wetland area would not be impacted.

General Accidental Release Prevention Program and Chemical-Specific Prevention Steps

The general Accidental Release Prevention Program and Chemical-Specific Prevention Steps are summarized below:

 Â¿Prevention of accidental releases of hazardous substances at the International Titanium Powder Ottawa facility involves a unified approach that integrates technologies, procedures, employee participation, and management practices.  These prevention programs comply with all applicable requirements of the EPA "Risk Management Program" (RMP), as stipulated in 40 CFR Part 68.  As a minimum, management and site employees actively participate in regularly scheduled safety meetings, operating and process hazards reviews, safety, engineering, and operating reviews and update training, and maintenance reliability programs for component and systems.Â¿

The building is equipped with a dike containment and central drain system (to dike area), smoke sensors which upon activation, will shut down the buildings tempered air HVAC system, and immediately bring on the fume collection/scrubber system for fume capture.  In addition, the building are will be equipped with surveillance cameras, and upon visual detection of a liquid spill, the control board operator will activate a permanent foam suppression system to the spill area which will suppress the fume evolution from the liquid spill.Â¿


Five Year Accident History

Since the ITP Ottawa facility is a new manufacturing facility, there is no five year history or record of any release of titanium tetrachloride that caused an offsite impact or caused employee injury.  Once the threshold quantity of titanium tetrachloride is present at the facility, the Â¿trigger eventÂ¿, the required history and records of any releases will be created and maintained.  

Emergency Response Program

The International Titanium Powder, LLC Manufacturing FacilityÂ¿s emergency response program involves the preparation of an Emergency Response Plan tailored to the process and emergency response services that are available in the nearby community. This plan complies with EPA "Emergency Response Program" requirements stipulated in 40 CFR Part 68. The emergency response program consists of an Emergency Response Plan, procedures, emergency contacts & communication plan, emergency response equipment, employee training, and drills to ensure the program is effective.  The City of Ottawa Fire Department is the primary responder for site emergencies.  No additional onsite fire fighting capability (beyond normal safety equipment) is maintained. The ITP Ottawa facility Emergency Response Plan includes specific actions to be taken in

response to an accidental release of a regulated substance and procedures for informing the public and local agencies responsible for responding to accidental releases. If a release should occur, the City of Ottawa Fire department would be contacted. Emergency health care is the responsibility of onsite individuals trained for this purpose.  Upon arrival of the fire department, the fire and rescue personnel take on this responsibility.
